question: A 60-year-old man is called for a follow-up 2 weeks after his surgery for colon cancer. During the surgery, his tumor was removed and a permanent stoma was made. What is the most likely procedure performed?
What is the most common site of metastasis of colorectal cancer?
What is the investigation of choice to determine patency of the distal portion of intestine prior to a defunctioning stoma reversal surgery?

A patient with Crohn’s disease presented to emergency with complaints of absolute constipation and vomiting. A short narrowing is noted in the mid transverse colon. What would be the most likely option to treat his condition?
Total protein requirement in critical care patients is:
What is the recommended daily intake of protein for an adult?
When aerial oxidation occurs of unsaturated fat what is this referred to?

A postgraduate surgical trainee has been asked to do closure of midline rectus sheath by the consultant. Which one of the following statements is correct in order to close the wound and avoid future hernias?

answers.option: Length of suture should be 4:1 of the wound length
Length of suture should be 1:1 of the wound length
Length of the suture should be 5:1 of the wound length
Length of the suture should be 3:1 of the wound length
Length of suture should be 1:2 of the wound length

question: What is the most common position of the appendix?
What is the most common site of diverticulosis?
A 45-year-old female is diagnosed with chronic cholecystitis due to cholelithiasis. What is the best treatment option?
A 55-year-old man with a history of ulcerative colitis for the last 20 years presents with a left iliac fossa mass. Which of the following can be the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the feature of small bowel dilation on X-ray?
What is a common cause of pseudoobstruction?
Which of the following is the appropriate intervention for a peptic ulcer with duodenal perforation?

answers.option: Keep omental patch and suture the defect

question: What causes post-operative paralytic ileus?
The endoscopy of a patient reveals an ulcerated mass on the antrum. A biopsy sample is sent and confirmed to be an adenocarcinoma. What is the most appropriate treatment?

A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with complaints of abdominal pain in the umbilical region which transfers to the right lower quadrant. According to the parents, the pain started 6 hours ago and did not subside. On examination, rebound tenderness is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the appropriate emergency surgery recommended for a patient with severe ulcerative colitis?

answers.option: Reserved proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

question: A 28-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department with the complaint of severe generalized body pain for the past 1 day that is associated with vomiting. She has also not passed any stool for the past 2 days. She has had colicky abdominal pain for the past 3 months and has lost a significant amount of weight. She has a pulse of 120 beats per minute, blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute, and she is afebrile. She has a distended tense tender abdomen with a tympanic note and her gut sounds are inaudible. What would be the most appropriate radiological investigation to reach a diagnosis for this patient?

A 21-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a complaint of colicky abdominal pain off-and-on along with low-grade evening fever for the past 3 months. He has had vomiting for the past 2 days and absolute constipation for 1 day. He has lost 7 kg in the last 3 months. He is anemic, dehydrated, has a pulse of 100 beats per minute, blood pressure of 100 mmHg, and weight of 40 kg. His abdomen is distended and is tympanic on auscultation with tenderness. Gut sounds are inaudible. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old female presents with the complaint of crampy abdominal pain and loose stools for the past 1 month with a frequency of 6-8/day. The stool was mixed with mucus and blood, with occasional blood clots seen. On examination, she has pallor and is lethargic. Her abdomen is tender in the right and left iliac fossa. A digital rectal examination shows a blood-stained finger with stool. Stool culture yields negative for any growth. Colonoscopy shows diffuse erythema of the entire colon with ulceration and spontaneous bleeding. Histopathology shows an increase in inflammatory cells in the lamina propria. The walls of the crypts of Lieberkuhn are infiltrated by inflammatory cells and there are crypt abscesses. What would be the most likely diagnosis in her case?

A 50-year-old caucasian male presents to the clinic with post-prandial abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, frequent oral aphthous ulceration, and weight loss for the past 6 months. He was advised upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy and colonoscopy by a family physician. The endoscopic appearance is suggestive of cobblestone. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male has been a known case of ulcerative colitis (biopsy proven) for the last 20 years with in-frequent flare-ups in between. He is currently stable on an aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) regimen. What is the chance of colorectal malignancy in this case?

A 30-year-old woman who has a history of ulcerative colitis for the past 5 years develops severe lower gastrointestinal bleeding necessitating blood transfusions frequently in the last 15 days. She is advised to undergo surgery on an emergent basis. What should be the ideal procedure in this case?

answers.option: Total abdominal colectomy with ileal anastomosis (TAC-IRA)
Restorative proctocolectomy with ileal pouch anal anastomosis (RPC-IPAA)

question: A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe pain in her right upper abdomen for the past 1 day. Pain radiated toward her right shoulder. On examination, she is febrile and has a severely tender right hypochondrium. Lab investigations show Hb 10 mg/dL and a total leukocyte count of 15,000/mm³. The remainder of her investigations are all normal. Ultrasound shows increased wall thickness of the gall bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old male presented to the emergency department with severe pain in his right lower abdomen for the past 1 hour. The pain was initially around the umbilicus but it has now radiated toward the right lower abdomen. The pain gets worse with movement. He is febrile, tachycardic, tachypneic, and has a narrow pulse pressure. He has a tender right iliac fossa with the presence of rebound tenderness. Lab investigations show Hb 15 mg/dL and a total leukocyte count of 25,000/mm³. The remainder of the investigations is all normal. Ultrasound shows a non-compressible tubular structure in the right iliac fossa and fluid in the pelvis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain. She is unable to sit straight and the pain decreases when she leans forward. She is febrile and tachycardic. Abdominal examination reveals severe tenderness in her epigastrium. A diagnosis of acute pancreatitis was made. Serum amylase and lipase levels were elevated. Ultrasound abdomen showed a swollen pancreas. Which of the following laboratory findings indicate a good prognosis?

A 45-year-old male with peptic ulcer disease presents to the emergency department with an abrupt onset of severe epigastric pain for the past 1 hour. Abdominal examination raises suspicion for an acute surgical abdomen. Which of the following examination findings is not suggestive of perforation?

answers.option: Chemical peritonitis progresses to abdominal rigidity, bacterial peritonitis, and sepsis
Tympanitic abdomen may indicate free air, confirmed by upright chest X-ray
A reactive pleural effusion is frequently seen with gastric perforation
Perforation accounts for two-thirds of peptic ulcer-related deaths
Acute pancreatitis may result from posterior perforation

question: In a clinically stable patient, immediate exploratory laparotomy is indicated in which of the following conditions?

A 26-year-old female is suspected of having acute appendicitis. On examination, he experiences abdominal pain during extension of right hip while lying on the left lateral posiition. Where do you suspect the location of the tip of her appendix?
A 15-year-old boy with suspected acute appendicitis has an Alvarado score of 5-6. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

A 50-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain and yellowing of the sclera. Which of the following is the best first-line investigation to do in this patient?

A 45-year-old male is presented complaining of vomiting off/on for one month. CT scan abdomen shows a cystic lesion in the tail of the pancreas compressing the stomach. Which of the following findings is indicative of the benign nature of the disease?

answers.option: Complex cystic lesion on endoscopic ultrasound
History of mild upper quadrant pain at least a month ago
Presence of atypical cells in cystic fluid
Cystic fluid amylase level of more than 3000 IU/L

question: A 30-year-old male presents in the emergency department with a history of severe abdominal pain. His laboratory investigation shows amylase of 3000IU/L. Which of the following prognostic factors is unfavorable for this patient?

A 38-year-old female presents in the emergency department with a history of severe pain in the epigastric region and multiple episodes of vomiting for one day and gets admitted as a case of acute pancreatitis. CT scan abdomen shows a CTSI of 8/10. After 2 days of conservative management, the pain has decreased but she is not tolerating it orally. which of the following routes is preferred for nutritional support?

A 30-year-old female experiences an acute episode of right hypochondriac pain following a meal. She has had a similar episode in the past that was managed conservatively. On examination, she holds her breath on deep palpation of the right hypochondrium. On ultrasound, there are gallstones with pericholecystic fluid present. what is the best initial step in management?

answers.option: Keep the patient NPO, start IV antibiotics and analgesic

question: A 35-year-old male presents in emergency, with severe abdominal pain since one day. He has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis one year back. On examination, his pulse is 120 beats/minute. Abdomen is tense and tender. There is free air under diaphragm in erect X-ray. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

answers.option: Colonoscopy and biopsy of terminal ileum

question: A 50-year-old man presents with something protruding from his rectum during defecation, accompanied by blood streaks in the stool. He can manually push it back inside. Which of the following is not a treatment option for his condition?

A patient complains of painful defecation to the extent that he avoids passing stool. There is a flush of blood during defecation. Proctoscopy reveals an anal fissure. Which of the following is a treatment option?
